caption: The Saint Thomas campus is really nice, the historic building hosts numerous classrooms and all of those I've been in are well furnished with new equipment and the personnel is very helpful, all around great place to learn and interact with other students!

If you have the chance to come to SciencesPo, then you should take it. It is one of the best universities for Political Science in the world, the professors are of the highest standard, and the environment is near perfect for studying. Hard work and dedication is a prerequisite though, selection can be brutal. I wish they had more outlets and computer friendly spaces, however they are in the process of renovating. I would give them 5 stars if they had proper student rooms, and at least a decent power-outlet setup. P.S. I met a cool German dude while studying at Sciences Po, who insisted I should mention him in this review.
I graduated from Sciences Po Paris a long time ago. "PES SECTION". Best time, experience ever ! Methodology, Methodology !! Best thoughts to all students. Herv√© Yves Arhant (living in London)

Since it is one of the schools with the grandes ecoles (elite school) tradition in France, it stands out both in the country and worldwide with its quality of education. As an Erasmus student, I had the chance to study for a semester (it coincided with COVID-19) and if I were to share my observations:  1-The rate of international students at the school is quite high, this rate is stated as 51 percent on the website. The reason it has such a high rate is that all final year students at the school have to complete it outside of France, and I think it's a great system. Even though I couldn't stay long due to corona, you have the chance to make friends from all over the world.  2- French students, who are the main element of the school, are hesitant to choose English courses and you will most likely not meet more than a few French people (Of course, the situation changes if you know French or are studying at the school for a long time).  3- The school's campus is located in Saint Germain, one of the most beautiful districts of the city. From here you can go to any corner of Paris quite easily. However, even eating fast food around the school starts from 15 euros. If you want to eat at the school canteen, your options are limited to a few sandwiches, but you can fill your stomach for a very reasonable price of 3 euros.  4- The school does not have dormitory facilities, but they will move to their new campus as of 2021. (Don't worry, it is in the city center.) In the new campus, graduate students will be provided with dormitory opportunities, albeit partially. In addition, the school has a department that deals with dormitories and you can easily find a dormitory. However, finding accommodation in Paris is a problem in itself, so be sure to create your own plan in advance.  5-Unlike Turkey, the English courses I take focus on practical training. For example, while the reading load at my school in Turkey is very heavy, here you are expected to be able to explain the text you read to the class and discuss it. However, since everyone was an international student like me, they didn't care much about the lessons, maybe it just seemed like that to me.  6- A significant part of the student profile is quite elite and rich. Since grande √©coles in France are paid, it is becoming increasingly difficult for the middle class to enter. However, Sciences Po has recently offered scholarships to one-fifth of its students in order to balance this inequality. Since T√ºrkiye is not a member of the EU, scholarship opportunities are naturally limited, but it is still not impossible. Although quite limited, there are also different scholarship opportunities for students outside the EU.
Years of bachelor's degree, then master's degree, then doctorate, then teaching... Our steps have been on this path since 2008 (I love this place)

Excellent! Top associations, pretty building and interior, magical amphitheater (with even more interventions from Professor Guillaume Tusseau). The teaching is of high quality, the atmosphere very pleasant. Even if the work overwhelms me (bicursus you know) I admit that I have a great time there

School of excellence and standards. Some say that it formats brains to form an elite. In reality, she transmits to her students a taste for analysis and critical thinking. Open to the world, its students are curious about everything and show great solidarity with each other. With an excellent associative network, this school really knows how to instill a spirit of cohesion.

The Good Samaritan security guard: ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs forbidden, wait outside‚Äù  Me: ‚ÄúOkay, can I at least stand on the porch while I wait?‚Äù  The good Samaritan watchman and his neighbor who came as reinforcement (in one voice): " "No, it's forbidden, wait outside; far from us, infamous non-possessor-of-the-map"

I have the impression, and it is surely only one, that all the demeaning and crushing comments about Sciences Po, without ample explanation, come from people not admitted to this school, and who, angrily, 'attack this school violently and without argument. Furthermore, I was able to note that all the people who have been to Sciences Po are generally satisfied with this institution which they consider to be excellent,

Hello everyone, I need help from Science Po students or others on how to pass admission. I spent high school in Japan (5 years ago) and I was not a very good student, I was at the Universidad de la Salle in Colombia (2 years ago) but for health reasons I returned to Japan and got a diploma in Japanese for foreigners. Now I improved my studies a little and I want to study again and I like political science. I want to know if there is a pre-university or courses to be able to pass admission or what I should do to enter.... I don't know how to speak French, what school do you recommend to learn French quickly... Thank you for reading, I wish you the best of your lives.
Good school. Prep.Ena is an interesting class. Teachers sometimes become ambassadors. Philosophy and history help with this course.  For those looking for an address book this may help...
